questions.text: Patient was started on HAART. What is used to monitor efficacy of treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Viral load Explanation: When a patient is started on HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) for HIV infection, the efficacy of treatment is primarily monitored by measuring the HIV viral load. Viral load refers to the amount of HIV RNA in the blood. A declining or undetectable viral load indicates that the therapy is effective in suppressing viral replication. Regular monitoring helps assess: Response to therapy Adherence to treatment Development of resistance Why not the other options? B. P24 antigen: Useful for early diagnosis of HIV before antibodies develop but not for ongoing treatment monitoring. C. HIV-1 antibody: Once positive, it typically remains positive for life, regardless of treatment success. D. Viral serotype: Not used to monitor treatment; it refers to identifying the type/subtype of HIV.

questions.text: A patient visited Africa and died of a disease. Autopsy showed intra nuclear Torres bodies. Which vaccine strain could have prevented this disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 17D Explanation: The 17D vaccine strain is the live attenuated vaccine for Yellow Fever, a flavivirus transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily in Africa and South America. Clue in the question: Visited Africa → Endemic area for Yellow Fever. Died of a disease with intranuclear Torres bodies → Torres bodies are eosinophilic inclusions seen in hepatocytes infected by Yellow Fever virus. This points to Yellow Fever, which is vaccine-preventable with the 17D strain. Why not the others? A. SA 14-14-2 → Vaccine for Japanese Encephalitis. C. Nakayama → Another Japanese Encephalitis vaccine strain. D. Jeryl-Lynn → Mumps vaccine strain (part of MMR).

questions.text: A truck driver admitted with cough and breathlessness. HPE revealed septate hyphae with 45deg angle branching as shown in the image. Identify the correct pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aspergillus Explanation: The key histopathological finding in this case is: Septate hyphae with acute angle (≈45°) branching This is characteristic of Aspergillus species, a filamentous fungus that commonly causes pulmonary aspergillosis, especially in people with underlying lung disease or immunosuppression. How to differentiate fungal pathogens based on morphology: Fungal Pathogen Hyphae Characteristics Branching Angle Septation Aspergillus Thin, uniform, acute angle branching ~45° Septate Mucor/Rhizopus Broad, ribbon-like, irregular branching ~90° Non-septate or sparsely septate Absidia Similar to Mucor/Rhizopus (Zygomycetes group) ~90° Non-septate

questions.text: A HIV positive person developed fever, Cough, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The infectious agent was in yeast form at 370 C and mold form at 220C. Produces red color pigment in the culture. Microscopy shown in the image. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Talaromyces marneffei. Reasoning: The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards Talaromyces marneffei, especially in an HIV-positive individual, due to the following key features: 1. Dimorphic Fungus: Yeast form at 37°C (body temperature) Mold form at 25–30°C (room temperature) This thermal dimorphism is characteristic of several pathogenic fungi, but Talaromyces marneffei is notable for this feature in Southeast Asia and among immunocompromised patients. 2. Red pigment production: T. marneffei uniquely produces a red soluble pigment on Sabouraud dextrose agar. This pigment is a hallmark diagnostic clue. 3. Clinical features: Fever, cough, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly — typical of disseminated talaromycosis. Common in AIDS patients, particularly with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL. 4. Microscopy: If the image shows oval yeast cells with transverse septa, that's a classic sign of T. marneffei in its yeast phase. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Aspergillus versicolor: Not dimorphic and does not produce red pigment. More commonly associated with superficial infections or allergic reactions, not disseminated systemic disease in HIV patients. B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in HIV, but it is a fungus with cystic forms, not dimorphic, and doesn't match the red pigment or systemic symptoms like hepatosplenomegaly. C. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Is dimorphic but does not produce red pigment. Common in North America and causes skin and lung disease.

questions.text: A farmer came with cauliflower like growth in foot. Biopsy shown copper penny or sclerotic bodies. Choose the correct diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chromoblastomycosis Explanation: The key clue is the "cauliflower-like growth" on the foot and the presence of "copper penny bodies" or sclerotic bodies on biopsy. Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by pigmented (dematiaceous) fungi such as Fonsecaea, Phialophora, and Cladophialophora species. The sclerotic bodies (also known as Medlar bodies, copper penny bodies, or muriform cells) are characteristic histopathological findings in chromoblastomycosis. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Sporotrichosis – Usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatics (sporotrichoid spread), not cauliflower-like growth, and does not show copper penny bodies. C. Mycetoma – Can also affect the foot and form granules, but shows grains or granules of fungi or bacteria, not sclerotic bodies. D. Cutaneous blastomycosis – Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis and presents with verrucous lesions, but does not show copper penny bodies on histology.

questions.text: A patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge. Choose the correct medium used to identify the species of this pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Candida Chrom agar Explanation: Curdy white vaginal discharge is characteristic of vulvovaginal candidiasis, most commonly caused by Candida species, especially Candida albicans. To identify and differentiate Candida species, the preferred medium is Candida Chrom agar. Candida Chrom agar: It is a selective and differential medium. Different Candida species produce distinctive colored colonies, aiding in rapid identification: Candida albicans – green Candida tropicalis – blue to purple Candida krusei – pink, fuzzy Why the other options are incorrect: A. SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) – Good for general fungal growth but does not differentiate species. B. Bird seed agar (Niger seed agar) – Used specifically for Cryptococcus neoformans, which produces brown colonies. D. Cornmeal agar – Used for morphological studies (e.g., formation of pseudohyphae, chlamydospores), not ideal for rapid species identification.

questions.text: A wrestler presented with itch in axilla. The organism produced velvety colonies with underside red colour pigment in culture . Microscopy shown pencil shaped macroconidia and abundant microconidia . Diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichophyton rubrum (T. rubrum) Explanation: Key features pointing to T. rubrum: Clinical presentation: Wrestler with itch in the axilla → common site for tinea corporis or tinea cruris. Wrestlers are at higher risk due to close skin contact ("tinea corporis gladiatorum"). Culture characteristics: Velvety colonies with a red pigment on the reverse (underside) are classic for T. rubrum. Microscopy: Shows pencil-shaped macroconidia. Abundant microconidia, typically teardrop or peg-shaped, along hyphae. Why other options are incorrect: B. T. mentagrophytes: Has more granular colonies and no red pigment on the reverse; shows spiral hyphae and grape-like clusters of microconidia. C. T. schoenleinii: Causes favus, forms favic chandeliers (antler-like hyphae); rare in this context. D. T. tonsurans: More commonly causes tinea capitis; produces variable microconidia and few macroconidia, not pencil-shaped.

questions.text: A 28 year old lady admitted with fever, nausea and anorexia for 2 months duration.HbsAg positive, anti HBc IgM positive. Anti HCV negative. Whats is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute hepatitis B Explanation: Key findings in the case: Symptoms: Fever, nausea, anorexia for 2 months — consistent with acute hepatitis. HBsAg positive: Indicates active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Anti-HBc IgM positive: This is the most specific marker of acute hepatitis B infection. Anti-HCV negative: Rules out hepatitis C. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Acute hepatitis C – Ruled out because anti-HCV is negative. B. Chronic hepatitis C – Also ruled out by anti-HCV negativity. D. Chronic hepatitis B – Would show HBsAg positive and anti-HBc IgG, not IgM.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came to emergency department with c/o fever for a week, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, calf pain, mild sore throat and conjunctival suffusion. No c/o vomiting, cough and hemorrhage. Urine output normal. No travel history. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Leptospirosis Explanation: This 12-year-old boy presents with a classic constellation of signs and symptoms suggestive of leptospirosis, a zoonotic bacterial infection caused by Leptospira species. Key Clinical Clues: Fever lasting a week Tender hepatomegaly and jaundice – suggests hepatic involvement Calf pain – a classic symptom in leptospirosis Mild sore throat and conjunctival suffusion – highly characteristic of leptospirosis Normal urine output – indicates no severe renal impairment yet No hemorrhage or travel history – less likely to be dengue or a tropical viral illness Why other options are incorrect: A. Chikungunya – More likely to cause rash and severe joint pains; hepatomegaly and conjunctival suffusion are not typical. C. Hepatitis A – Can cause fever and jaundice but does not typically cause calf pain or conjunctival suffusion. D. Dengue hemorrhagic fever – Would usually present with bleeding manifestations, low platelet count, and signs of plasma leakage, which are absent here.

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
Pseudo membrane contains leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris.

questions.text: What is false about pseudo membrane colitis/ C. difficle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IgM is diagnostic — FALSE statement Explanation: Pseudomembranous colitis, caused by Clostridioides difficile (formerly Clostridium difficile), is a toxin-mediated colonic disease, typically following antibiotic use. Analysis of each option: A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment – True Fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic used orally to treat C. difficile infections. It is especially useful for preventing recurrence. B. IgM is diagnostic – False Diagnosis is not based on IgM antibodies. Instead, it relies on detection of C. difficile toxins (A and B) in stool via enzyme immunoassay (EIA), PCR, or toxigenic culture. C. It is toxin mediated – True The disease is caused by toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin) produced by C. difficile. D. Pseudomembrane contains leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris – True Histologically, pseudomembranes consist of necrotic epithelial cells, leukocytes, fibrin, and mucus, forming the yellow-white plaques seen on colonoscopy.

questions.text: A patient was admitted due to sepsis and broad-spectrum antibiotic started. She developed diarrhea. What is used to identify the etiology of diarrhea ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) GDH antigen and toxin assay Explanation: A patient develops diarrhea after starting broad-spectrum antibiotics — this is highly suggestive of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). To identify the etiology, the recommended initial testing strategy involves: Glutamate Dehydrogenase (GDH) Antigen + Toxin A/B Assay: GDH antigen: Detects the presence of C. difficile organism (high sensitivity). Toxin assay: Detects toxins A and B (high specificity, confirms pathogenic strain). This two-step algorithm increases diagnostic accuracy. Why other options are incorrect: A. GDH Ag only – Cannot differentiate between toxin-producing and non-toxigenic strains; high sensitivity but low specificity. C. Stool microscopy – Not useful for C. difficile; cannot detect toxins or differentiate species. D. Aerobic culture – C. difficile is anaerobic; and even anaerobic culture is time-consuming and not routinely used.

questions.text: A soldier presented with fever, myalgia, rash in body sparing palm and sole. Five other soldiers in the troop also affected with similar illness. H/o exposure to body lice present . Choose the correct Causative organism ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rickettsia prowazekii Explanation: This case describes a classic presentation of epidemic typhus, which is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Key features pointing to R. prowazekii: Fever, myalgia, rash sparing palms and soles. Multiple cases in close quarters (suggests outbreak). Exposure to body lice — this is the primary vector for R. prowazekii. Seen in settings like military troops, refugee camps, or crowded unsanitary conditions. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Rickettsia typhi – Causes endemic (murine) typhus, transmitted by fleas, not lice. C. Rickettsia akari – Causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites; associated with papulovesicular rash. D. Rickettsia conorii – Causes Mediterranean spotted fever or Indian tick typhus, with rash involving palms and soles; transmitted by ticks, not lice.

questions.text: A diabetic patient had rhinitis, facial swelling. Biopsy showed aseptate hyphae with irregular obtuse branching. Drug of choice for this ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amphotericin B Explanation: This case describes mucormycosis (zygomycosis), a life-threatening fungal infection often seen in diabetics, especially with ketoacidosis. Key clues: Diabetic patient Rhinitis and facial swelling – typical early signs of rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis Biopsy: Aseptate hyphae with irregular, obtuse (broad-angle) branching – classic histological feature of Mucorales species (e.g., Rhizopus, Mucor, Rhizomucor) Treatment: First-line drug: Liposomal Amphotericin B Broad antifungal with activity against Mucorales Administered IV, often along with surgical debridement Why other options are incorrect: B. Fluconazole – Ineffective against Mucorales. C. Voriconazole – Active against Aspergillus, but not effective against Mucorales; may worsen prognosis if used mistakenly. D. Caspofungin – Echinocandins like caspofungin are not active against Mucorales.

choices.text: Stop breast feeding and start ART
Test for IgM antibodies of giardia and start antibiotics

questions.text: A 4-month-old child born to HIV positive mother developed recurrent diarrhea . What is the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dried blood for HIV PCR Explanation: In a 4-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother with recurrent diarrhea, the most appropriate next step is to perform an HIV PCR test using dried blood spot. Why? Maternal HIV antibodies cross the placenta and can remain in the infant's circulation for up to 18 months, making HIV antibody tests (Option C) unreliable in infants. HIV PCR (DNA or RNA) detects viral nucleic acids, making it the gold standard for early infant diagnosis (usually from 6 weeks of age). Why other options are incorrect: A. Stop breastfeeding and start ART – Premature. ART should be started only after confirming the diagnosis. Breastfeeding guidance depends on maternal ART status and local protocols. C. Test for HIV antibody – Not useful under 18 months due to maternal antibody interference. D. Test for Giardia IgM and start antibiotics – May be relevant later, but first priority is to assess for underlying HIV infection which predisposes to recurrent infections.

choices.text: Caused by both bacteria and fungi

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer admitted with sinuses with discharging granules in the foot. Microscopy of the granule shown in the image. Choose the true statement
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Caused by both bacteria and fungi Explanation: The clinical presentation — sinuses with discharging granules from the foot in a farmer — strongly suggests mycetoma (also known as Madura foot). Microscopy of granules: These grains or granules are compact colonies of organisms surrounded by immune cells and tissue debris. Microscopy helps distinguish between actinomycetoma (bacterial) and eumycetoma (fungal). Key point: Mycetoma can be caused by: Bacteria – called actinomycetoma (e.g., Nocardia, Actinomadura, Streptomyces) Fungi – called eumycetoma (e.g., Madurella, Exophiala) Hence, it is true that mycetoma is caused by both bacteria and fungi. Why other options are incorrect: A. It causes only superficial disease – False. Mycetoma is chronic and deep, involving subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone. B. Hematogenous spread – Rare. Mycetoma typically spreads locally, not through the bloodstream. D. Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon – Not a typical feature of mycetoma. This is seen in some parasitic or fungal infections like sporotrichosis, schistosomiasis, or eosinophilic granulomas, but not in mycetoma granules.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nucleus in the tail tip suggestive of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Brugia malayi Explanation: Identification of microfilariae on microscopy is based on: Sheath presence Tail morphology Arrangement of nuclei in the tail Brugia malayi distinguishing features: Sheathed microfilariae Two discrete nuclei in the tail tip Tail is kinked, with terminal and subterminal nuclei distinctly separated These features help differentiate it from Wuchereria bancrofti, which also has a sheath but no nuclei in the tail tip. Comparison with other options: A. Loa loa – Sheathed, but nuclei extend to the tail tip continuously, not two distinct ones. C. Wuchereria bancrofti – Sheathed, but no nuclei at the tail tip. D. Mansonella ozzardi – Unsheathed, and no nuclei at the tail tip.

choices.text: Inhibits the release of Acetyl choline

questions.text: Choose the correct MoA of botulinum toxin.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inhibits the release of Acetylcholine Explanation: Botulinum toxin, produced by Clostridium botulinum, is one of the most potent neurotoxins known. Mechanism of Action (MoA): It inhibits the release of acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction by cleaving SNARE proteins required for vesicle fusion. This leads to flaccid paralysis, as muscles are unable to contract. Why other options are incorrect: A. Stimulate nicotinic receptors – Botulinum toxin doesn't stimulate receptors; it prevents neurotransmitter release. C. Stimulate muscarinic receptors – It does not act on receptors directly, nor stimulate parasympathetic responses. D. Stimulate the release of norepinephrine – Botulinum toxin affects cholinergic (ACh) neurons, not adrenergic ones.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium with neck rigidity. CSF analysis shows slight decrease in glucose and increase in proteins. Microscopy – predominantly lymphocytes seen. A coagulum of CSF seen as shown in the image. Choose the correct diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tubercular meningitis Explanation: The clinical and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings are highly suggestive of tubercular meningitis (TBM). Key clues: Fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity — classic signs of meningitis CSF analysis: Slight decrease in glucose (moderate hypoglycorrhachia) Increased protein Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis Coagulum in CSF (often described as a "cobweb" or "spider web" clot) — this is characteristic of TB meningitis, due to high fibrin content in proteinaceous CSF Why other options are incorrect: A. Pyogenic meningitis – Usually shows markedly low glucose, very high protein, and predominantly neutrophils, not lymphocytes. B. Viral meningitis – Typically has normal glucose, mild protein elevation, and lymphocytes, but no CSF clot. D. Chemical meningitis – May resemble infectious meningitis, but lacks classic cobweb coagulum, and is usually a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.text: MDR TB refers to resistant to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Isoniazid + Rifampicin Explanation: MDR-TB (Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis) is defined as tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that is resistant to at least: Isoniazid (INH) and Rifampicin (RIF) These two drugs are the most powerful first-line anti-TB medications, and resistance to both constitutes MDR-TB. Why other options are incorrect: A. Rifampicin + Kanamycin – Kanamycin is a second-line injectable drug. Resistance to it is not part of MDR-TB definition. B. Isoniazid + Rifampicin + Kanamycin – This represents pre-XDR or XDR-TB, not basic MDR-TB. D. Isoniazid + Fluoroquinolones – Resistance to fluoroquinolones plus MDR-TB defines pre-XDR TB, not MDR-TB alone.

questions.text: A 20 year female working in a village school developed watery diarrhea with rice water stool. The pathogen responsible for this condition acts on
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GM1 ganglioside receptor Explanation: The clinical scenario — a 20-year-old woman with watery diarrhea and "rice water stools" — is characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. Pathogenesis of Cholera: Cholera toxin (CTX) is the main virulence factor. It is an AB? exotoxin, where: The B subunit binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells. The A subunit activates adenylate cyclase via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, increasing cAMP levels. This leads to massive secretion of chloride and water into the intestinal lumen → profuse watery diarrhea ("rice water stool"). Why the other options are incorrect: B. GM2 ganglioside receptor – Associated with certain neurological toxins, not cholera. C. Cerebroganglioside receptor – Nonspecific and not involved in cholera. D. Sphingomyelin receptor – Not relevant to cholera toxin; more associated with some bacterial or viral infections (e.g., Listeria, Shiga toxin).

questions.text: Female came with a clinical condition as shown in the image. HPE shows she’s having high risk for squamous cell atypia. Which is responsible for this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) HPV 18 The image shows genital warts, often caused by low-risk HPV types like 6 and 11. However, the crucial detail in the text is "HPE shows she's having high risk for squamous cell atypia." High-risk HPV types are specifically associated with an increased risk of developing precancerous squamous cell atypia and subsequent progression to cancer. Among the given options, HPV 18 is a well-established high-risk (oncogenic) HPV type, responsible for a significant percentage of anogenital cancers, particularly cervical cancer and adenocarcinoma. While HPV 11 typically causes benign warts, it is not generally classified as "high risk" for squamous cell atypia with oncogenic potential in the same manner as HPV 18. Therefore, the mention of "high risk for squamous cell atypia" strongly points to an infection with an oncogenic HPV type like HPV 18, even if a low-risk type might also be present causing the visible warts.

questions.text: A patient came with unilateral lymphadenopathy. Sheathed Organism with no nuclei at the tail tip seen in the microscope. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wuchereria bancrofti Explanation: Wuchereria bancrofti is the most common cause of lymphatic filariasis, which typically presents as unilateral lymphadenopathy or lymphedema. The microfilariae of W. bancrofti are sheathed, and a key identifying feature on microscopy is that they have no nuclei at the tip of the tail (the tail tip is clear). This microscopic characteristic helps differentiate W. bancrofti from other filarial species. The clinical presentation and these microscopic findings strongly support W. bancrofti as the correct pathogen in this case. Incorrect Options: B. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi microfilariae are sheathed but differ by having two distinct nuclei at the tail tip, which is not seen here. It also causes lymphatic filariasis but is less common and has different endemic areas. C. Loa loa: Loa loa microfilariae are sheathed and have nuclei extending continuously to the tail tip. Clinically, it causes calabar swellings and migrates through subcutaneous tissue rather than causing significant lymphadenopathy. D. Brugia timori: Brugia timori is another cause of lymphatic filariasis, endemic to limited regions, but its microfilariae have nuclei extending into the tail tip, unlike W. bancrofti.

questions.text: A clinician, clinically diagnosed a case of brucellosis, and ordered Standard agglutination test for brucellosis. It showed negative. But after serial dilution of serum, it become positive. Choose the Correct cause for this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pro zone Explanation: The prozone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antibodies in the serum, which interferes with the optimal formation of antigen-antibody complexes necessary for visible agglutination. In the context of the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) for brucellosis, a very high antibody concentration can prevent agglutination from occurring, resulting in a false-negative test at lower dilutions. When the serum is serially diluted, the antibody concentration falls into the optimal range, allowing proper lattice formation and a positive agglutination test. This is a classic example of the prozone effect causing initial false-negative results. Incorrect Options: B. Post zone: The post zone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antigen relative to antibodies, which can also inhibit agglutination. However, this usually happens with antigen excess, not antibody excess, and is less common in serological tests like brucellosis SAT. C. Incomplete antibody: Incomplete antibodies (also called non-agglutinating antibodies) are antibodies that do not cause visible agglutination by themselves. They are not responsible for false-negative SAT results that become positive on dilution. D. Blocking antibody: Blocking antibodies interfere with the formation of visible immune complexes but are not typically the cause of dilution-dependent positivity in agglutination tests.

questions.text: A child admitted with fever, rash begins behind the ears, conjunctivitis, Coryza, cough and Koplik spot . Based on the clinical manifestations, choose the correct description of the pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ss enveloped RNA virus Explanation: The clinical presentation — fever, rash starting behind the ears, conjunctivitis, coryza, cough, and Koplik spots — is classic for measles. The causative agent of measles is the Measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. It is a single-stranded (ss) RNA virus that is enveloped. The envelope helps the virus enter host cells and evade the immune system. The virus is negative-sense ssRNA, but the key point here is ssRNA and enveloped. Why other options are incorrect: B. ds enveloped RNA virus: Double-stranded RNA viruses are rare in humans and measles is not one of them. Also, no common dsRNA enveloped virus causes this clinical picture. C. ss naked RNA virus: Measles virus is enveloped, not naked. Naked ssRNA viruses include enteroviruses like poliovirus. D. ds naked RNA virus: There are no known dsRNA naked viruses causing measles-like illness.

questions.text: A patient from UP admitted with fever, hepatosplenomegaly. His Bone marrow biopsy shown the pathogen with kinetoplast. Choose the correct vector for this pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sandfly Explanation: The clinical picture of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone marrow biopsy revealing a pathogen with a kinetoplast is characteristic of Leishmaniasis. The kinetoplast is a distinctive DNA-containing structure found in certain protozoa of the family Trypanosomatidae, which includes Leishmania species. The vector for Leishmania species is the Sandfly (genus Phlebotomus in the Old World, including India). The disease caused, especially in places like UP (Uttar Pradesh), is Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar). The parasite multiplies inside macrophages and is identifiable on bone marrow smear or biopsy by its kinetoplast. Why other options are incorrect: B. Tsetse fly: Vector for Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness). Not found in India and does not cause Leishmaniasis. C. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for Plasmodium species causing malaria. Malaria parasites do not have kinetoplasts. D. Triatome infestans: Vector for Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease in South America. Not relevant here.

questions.text: A child admitted with bloody diarrhoea with one day duration. The pathogen is obligate aerobe. Choose the correct enrichment medium for the pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Selenite F broth Explanation: The clinical presentation of bloody diarrhea lasting for one day suggests infection with Shigella or Salmonella species. Among these, Shigella is a facultative anaerobe but is often isolated using enrichment media designed to suppress competing gut flora. Selenite F broth is a selective enrichment medium specifically designed to enhance the growth of Salmonella and Shigella from stool samples by inhibiting competing bacteria. It favors the growth of these pathogens, facilitating their isolation on subsequent plating. Since the pathogen is obligate aerobe in the question (note: Shigella and Salmonella are facultative anaerobes, but the question likely emphasizes enrichment for a pathogen causing bloody diarrhea and requiring this medium), selenite F broth is commonly used for Salmonella and Shigella. Why other options are incorrect: A. Alkaline peptone water: Used as enrichment for Vibrio species, particularly Vibrio cholerae, which causes watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea. B. RCM (Reinforced Clostridial Medium): Selective for Clostridium species, anaerobic bacteria that cause different diseases (like gas gangrene, pseudomembranous colitis). D. BHI broth (Brain Heart Infusion broth): General-purpose nutrient broth, not selective or enrichment for enteric pathogens causing bloody diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient presents with Painless indurated ulcer on his penis with non tender lymphadenopathy. Motility of the organism best visualized by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dark field microscope Explanation: The clinical presentation of a painless indurated ulcer on the penis with non-tender lymphadenopathy is classic for primary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. This bacterium is a spirochete, which is thin and spiral-shaped, making it difficult to visualize with standard light microscopy. The dark field microscope is the best tool to visualize the motility of Treponema pallidum in clinical specimens such as lesion exudate. It enhances contrast by illuminating the specimen against a dark background, allowing the delicate, thin spirochetes to be seen clearly moving. Why other options are incorrect: A. Light microscope: Regular light microscopy cannot easily visualize Treponema pallidum due to its thinness and transparency. B. Electron microscope: Electron microscopy provides very high resolution but is impractical for routine clinical diagnosis and does not visualize motility. D. Fluorescent microscope: Used for specific fluorescent antibody staining but not for observing motility in routine clinical settings.

questions.text: Culture isolate from a patient with 70% burns is obligate aerobe. It shows positive for the test shown in the image. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pseudomonas aeruginosa Explanation: In patients with severe burns (70% body surface), Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common and serious opportunistic pathogen that frequently causes infections. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an obligate aerobe, meaning it requires oxygen to grow. It produces a positive oxidase test (the test likely shown in your image), which distinguishes it from many other gram-negative rods like E. coli and Proteus species. It also forms characteristic greenish-blue pigments (pyocyanin) and has a fruity odor in culture. Why other options are incorrect: B. Escherichia coli: Facultative anaerobe and oxidase negative. C. Proteus vulgaris: Facultative anaerobe and oxidase negative. D. Neisseria meningitidis: Oxidase positive but is a diplococcus usually causing meningitis, not common in burn wound infections. Also, not an obligate aerobe like Pseudomonas.

questions.text: Two friends developed vomiting after had dinner in the party. They ate many items except pastry. Next day they had vomiting. Which organism involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Emetic toxin of Bacillus cereus Explanation: The scenario describes vomiting occurring after eating at a party, with onset within hours (next day, likely within 1–6 hours), and the fact that they ate multiple items except pastry. This is classic for Bacillus cereus food poisoning caused by the emetic toxin. The emetic form of Bacillus cereus intoxication is associated with fried rice and pasta (starchy foods), but the question implies that they avoided pastry, which commonly is associated with this toxin. The incubation period is short (1-6 hours), and symptoms are mainly nausea and vomiting. Bacillus cereus produces a heat-stable emetic toxin that causes this rapid onset vomiting. Why other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcal enterotoxin: Causes food poisoning with vomiting and diarrhea, usually within 1–6 hours, often associated with contaminated dairy or meat products but the question highlights avoidance of pastry, which is typical for Bacillus cereus emetic toxin. C. Shigella toxin: Causes dysentery and bloody diarrhea, not rapid vomiting after a meal. D. E. coli Labile toxin: Causes watery diarrhea (traveler’s diarrhea) with longer incubation, not vomiting.

questions.text: A PLHIV came with fever, cough with sputum and rigor. His CD4 count is 55mm3. On examination, there is coarse respiratory sound in right lower lobe and x ray shows right lower lobe consolidation. Choose the correct pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pneumococci Explanation: A PLHIV (person living with HIV) with a CD4 count of 55/mm³ is severely immunocompromised. The patient presents with fever, productive cough with sputum, rigors, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray. This clinical picture is consistent with bacterial pneumonia, and among common pathogens, Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococci) is the most frequent cause of community-acquired pneumonia, including in HIV patients. Pneumococcal pneumonia typically presents acutely with fever, productive cough, rigors, and lobar consolidation. Why other options are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus: Can cause pneumonia, often post-influenza or in hospital settings, and may cause cavitary lesions. Not the most common cause here. C. Pneumocystis jiroveci: Classically causes interstitial pneumonia (PCP), with non-productive cough, gradual onset, and diffuse bilateral infiltrates on X-ray, not lobar consolidation. D. Mycoplasma: Causes atypical pneumonia, often in young adults with non-productive cough, mild symptoms, and patchy infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent urticaria with eosinophilia. BAL shows numerous small larvae in microscopy. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Strongyloides stercoralis Explanation: The presentation of recurrent urticaria with eosinophilia suggests a parasitic infection with an allergic or hypersensitivity component. The presence of numerous small larvae in BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage) microscopy indicates the larval migratory phase through the lungs, typical of Strongyloides stercoralis. Strongyloides has a unique life cycle that includes autoinfection and larval migration through the lungs causing Löffler’s syndrome, presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia. The larva seen in BAL confirms pulmonary involvement by Strongyloides. Why other options are incorrect: A. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes perianal itching; no lung migration or larvae in BAL. C. Ancylostoma caninum: Primarily a dog hookworm; human infection causes cutaneous larva migrans, not pulmonary larval migration or BAL larvae. D. Capillaria philippinensis: Causes intestinal capillariasis with diarrhea and malabsorption, no pulmonary phase with larvae in BAL.

questions.text: Hair perforation test is positive in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Trichophyton mentagrophytes Explanation: The hair perforation test is a laboratory test used to differentiate dermatophyte species based on their ability to perforate hair shafts in vitro. Trichophyton mentagrophytes produces positive hair perforation test results by causing grooves or perforations on the hair cuticle. This characteristic helps distinguish it from other species that do not show this behavior. Why other options are incorrect: A. Trichophyton rubrum: Usually shows a negative hair perforation test; it does not produce significant hair perforations. C. Microsporum audouinii: Does not perforate hair in this test; it generally invades hair differently and is negative in hair perforation test. D. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not infect hair; it primarily infects skin and nails, so the test is negative.

questions.text: Patient develops sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, and weakness and swollen, tender and painful lymph nodes with blackish discoloration of peripheral limbs. Clinician suspected a bacterial etiology which rat is the reservoir. Choose the correct vector for this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Xenopsylla species Explanation: The clinical presentation of sudden fever, headache, chills, weakness, swollen tender lymph nodes (bubo), and blackish discoloration of peripheral limbs is characteristic of plague. The bacterium Yersinia pestis is the causative agent of plague. Rats are the primary reservoirs of Yersinia pestis. The vector transmitting plague from rats to humans is the rat flea, Xenopsylla species. The flea bites humans and transmits the bacteria, causing bubonic plague (lymphadenopathy with bubo) and can lead to septicemic plague, which explains the blackish discoloration (gangrene) of extremities. Why other options are incorrect: B. Triatome species: Vector of Trypanosoma cruzi causing Chagas disease, not plague. C. Aedes aegypti: Mosquito vector for dengue, chikungunya, yellow fever, not plague. D. Simulium fly: Vector for Onchocerca volvulus (river blindness), not plague.

choices.text: She is susceptible to develop chickenpox

questions.text: A pregnant women came to contact with a varicella patient. Her antibody is tested for VZA and was negative. Choose the correct statement.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) She is susceptible to develop chickenpox Explanation: The patient is pregnant and had contact with a varicella (chickenpox) patient. Her antibody test for Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) is negative, meaning no immunity. Since she has no antibodies, she is susceptible to primary infection, which is chickenpox. Chickenpox during pregnancy can cause serious complications for both mother and fetus, so identifying susceptibility is important. Why other options are incorrect: A. She is susceptible to zoster: Zoster (shingles) results from reactivation of latent VZV in someone previously infected. If she is seronegative, she never had primary infection, so she cannot get shingles yet. C. She is immune to chickenpox: Negative antibody means no immunity, so this is incorrect. D. She is immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster requires prior chickenpox infection; she is seronegative, so no immunity.

questions.text: There is a blood spill in Operation theater. Choose the correct agent used to clean the blood spill.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypochlorite Explanation: In healthcare settings, blood spills pose a risk of transmitting blood-borne pathogens like HIV, HBV, and HCV. Sodium hypochlorite (bleach) is the preferred disinfectant for cleaning blood spills because it is a broad-spectrum, fast-acting, and effective agent that kills viruses, bacteria, and spores. It is commonly used in a concentration of 1:10 dilution (10%) for blood spills to ensure proper disinfection. Why other options are incorrect: A. Lysol: A general disinfectant, but not as effective or recommended specifically for blood spills, especially for blood-borne viruses. B. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Effective against many bacteria but less effective against viruses, and not recommended for blood spills. D. Cresol: Phenolic compound, used as a disinfectant but less common and more toxic, not preferred for blood spills.

questions.text: A male presented with the following finding as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gonorrhoea, here’s a detailed explanation for the diagnosis and why the other options are less likely: Explanation of the correct answer: Gonorrhoea Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Clinically, it presents with purulent urethral discharge, often yellowish or greenish, and dysuria (painful urination). The image likely shows a male patient with urethral discharge, which is classic for gonorrhoea. Gonorrhoea commonly causes acute onset of symptoms, and the discharge is typically thick, purulent, and profuse. Diagnosis can be confirmed by Gram stain showing Gram-negative intracellular diplococci and culture. Why other options are less likely: B. Herpes: Herpes simplex virus causes painful vesicles and ulcers on the genitalia, not purulent discharge. C. Syphilis: Primary syphilis presents as a painless ulcer (chancre), not with purulent urethral discharge. D. Ureaplasma: Ureaplasma infection may cause non-gonococcal urethritis with mild discharge, often less purulent and less acute.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for zika virus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aedes aegypti Explanation: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. This mosquito is a daytime feeder and also transmits other viruses such as dengue and chikungunya. The mosquito breeds in stagnant water found around human habitation, making it an urban vector. Zika virus infection is associated with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and in pregnant women, it can cause microcephaly in the fetus. Why other options are incorrect: B. Phlebotomus: Vector for Leishmania parasites causing leishmaniasis, not Zika virus. C. Culex: Vector for West Nile virus and some encephalitis viruses, not primarily Zika. D. Anopheles: Vector for malaria parasites (Plasmodium species), not Zika virus.

questions.text: A man from a tribal area of Jharkhand reports with fever for last 3 days. Peripheral blood is collected and stained with Giemsa. A diagnosis as malaria is made. The smear is shown in the fig. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Plasmodium falciparum Explanation: Plasmodium falciparum is the most severe form of malaria and is common in many parts of India, including tribal areas like Jharkhand. On Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear, P. falciparum shows: Multiple ring forms inside a single red blood cell (RBC). "Banana-shaped" or crescent-shaped gametocytes (a distinctive feature). Often, trophozoites are delicate rings with one or two chromatin dots. RBCs usually appear normal in size (no enlargement or stippling). Absence of schizonts and mature trophozoites in peripheral blood because they sequester in deep tissues. The clinical picture of fever for 3 days, plus the presence of typical features on smear, supports P. falciparum infection. Why other options are less likely: B. P. vivax: Shows enlarged RBCs with amoeboid trophozoites and Schuffner’s dots; gametocytes are round or oval, not banana-shaped. C. P. malariae: Has band forms in RBCs and rosette schizonts; RBCs usually not enlarged. D. P. ovale: Causes oval, enlarged RBCs with fimbriated edges; less common in India.

questions.text: A 12 years old boy presents with vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Staphylococcus aureus Explanation: The boy developed vomiting within 3 hours of eating food at a party. This rapid onset of symptoms is typical of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning, which is caused by ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food. The incubation period for S. aureus toxin is usually 1 to 6 hours, with vomiting as the predominant symptom. Common foods involved include cream-filled pastries, custards, and mayonnaise-based salads. Why other options are less likely: A. Salmonella: Has a longer incubation period (6 to 48 hours) and typically causes diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps rather than isolated vomiting. B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism characterized by neurological symptoms such as blurred vision, muscle weakness, not just vomiting. D. Clostridium perfringens: Usually causes diarrhea and abdominal cramps after 8 to 16 hours, vomiting is less common and onset is slower.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Candidiasis Explanation: The patient is HIV positive with a CD4 count of 300/cumm, which puts them at risk for opportunistic infections. The mucosal lesions in the mouth combined with microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae is characteristic of oral candidiasis. Candida albicans is the most common cause of oral candidiasis, presenting as white plaques that can be wiped off, leaving an erythematous base. Oral candidiasis is common in immunocompromised patients, including those with HIV infection. Why other options are incorrect: A. Oral hairy leukoplakia: Caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), presents as white, non-removable, corrugated patches on the lateral tongue, but no yeasts or pseudohyphae on microscopy. C. Lichen planus: A chronic inflammatory condition showing white lacy patches or erosions in the mouth, but no fungal elements on microscopy. D. Vitamin deficiency: May cause mucosal changes like glossitis or stomatitis but not budding yeasts or pseudohyphae.

questions.text: Superantigens not produced by which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Staphylococcus epidermidis Explanation: Superantigens are exotoxins that can non-specifically activate a large population of T cells by binding to MHC class II and T-cell receptors outside the conventional antigen-binding site, leading to massive cytokine release and systemic effects like toxic shock. Staphylococcus aureus produces several superantigens including Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin-1 (TSST-1) and enterotoxins responsible for food poisoning. Streptococcus pyogenes produces superantigens called streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins which are implicated in scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome. Clostridium perfringens produces toxins (like alpha-toxin), but it is not typically classified as a major producer of superantigens. However, some strains can produce toxins with superantigen-like activity. Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is generally not known to produce superantigens. It is mostly associated with biofilm-related infections on prosthetic devices but lacks the typical exotoxins and superantigens produced by S. aureus. Why other options are incorrect: A. Streptococcus pyogenes: Produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (superantigens). B. Clostridium perfringens: Though mainly known for other toxins, some strains can have superantigen-like toxins. C. Staphylococcus aureus: Well-known producer of several superantigens like TSST-1.

questions.text: Which of the following is a category A bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bacillus anthracis Explanation: Category A bioterrorism agents are those organisms or toxins that pose the highest risk to national security because they: Can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person. Result in high mortality rates and have the potential for major public health impact. Might cause public panic and require special preparedness. Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is classified as a Category A agent by the CDC. It can form spores that survive harsh conditions, be aerosolized, and cause severe disease with high fatality if untreated. It has been historically used as a bioweapon. Why other options are incorrect: A. Coxiella burnetii: Causes Q fever, a zoonotic disease, but is classified as a Category B agent due to moderate ease of dissemination and lower mortality. B. Brucella species: Cause brucellosis, also a Category B agent due to moderate impact and transmission. C. Nipah virus: An emerging zoonotic virus with high mortality but currently not classified as Category A by CDC for bioterrorism.

questions.text: Which of the following help in bacterial adhesion to host cells?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fimbriae Explanation: Fimbriae (also called pili) are hair-like proteinaceous appendages on the surface of many bacteria. They are primarily responsible for attachment (adhesion) to host cells by binding to specific receptors on the host tissue. This adhesion is the first step in colonization and infection. Examples include Escherichia coli fimbriae that help it attach to urinary tract epithelium. Why other options are incorrect: A. Cytoplasmic membrane: The inner membrane that controls transport and metabolic processes but is not involved in direct adhesion to host cells. B. Mesosomes: Infoldings of the bacterial plasma membrane seen in some bacteria (likely an artifact) with no role in adhesion. D. LPS (Lipopolysaccharide): Part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, important for immune activation and structural integrity, but not involved in adhesion.

choices.text: Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose agar

questions.text: The selective medium for E.coli 0157:H7 is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sorbitol MacConkey agar Explanation: E. coli O157:H7 is a Shiga toxin-producing strain and an important cause of hemorrhagic colitis. Unlike most E. coli strains, O157:H7 cannot ferment sorbitol. Sorbitol MacConkey (SMAC) agar is a selective and differential medium designed to isolate E. coli O157:H7: Most E. coli strains ferment sorbitol and produce pink/red colonies. E. coli O157:H7 colonies remain colorless or pale because they do not ferment sorbitol. This property helps distinguish O157:H7 from other E. coli strains. Why other options are incorrect: A. Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate agar: Used primarily for Salmonella and Shigella isolation, not for E. coli O157:H7. C. Thiosulfate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) agar: Selective medium for Vibrio species (like Vibrio cholerae), unrelated to E. coli. D. Thayer Martin medium: Selective medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis, not E. coli.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common soil transmitted helminthic infection in India characterized by eggs in stool as shown in the figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichuris Explanation: Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is a common soil-transmitted helminth in India and many tropical countries. The diagnosis is often made by identifying characteristic eggs in stool microscopy. The eggs of Trichuris are barrel-shaped or football-shaped with bipolar plugs (clear protrusions at both ends). These eggs are quite distinctive and help differentiate Trichuris from other helminths. Why other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are oval and have a thick, rough outer shell with a mammillated surface but lack bipolar plugs. C. Enterobius: Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) eggs are small, oval, and flattened on one side, typically diagnosed by perianal swab rather than stool microscopy. D. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma (hookworm) eggs are oval with thin shells and contain developing embryos; morphology differs from Trichuris.

questions.text: Antimicrobial property of bleaching powder is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypochlorous acid Explanation: The antimicrobial property of bleaching powder (calcium hypochlorite) is primarily due to the release of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) when it reacts with water. HOCl is a strong oxidizing agent that penetrates microbial cell walls and denatures proteins, enzymes, and nucleic acids, effectively killing bacteria, viruses, and fungi. It is more effective than chlorine gas or other chlorine compounds due to its neutral charge, which allows better interaction with negatively charged microbial surfaces. Bleaching powder, when dissolved in water, forms: scss Copy Edit Ca(OCl)? + H?O → Ca²? + 2HOCl Incorrect Options: B. Chloroform: Not related to the action of bleaching powder. Chloroform is a solvent, not an antimicrobial agent derived from bleach. C. Chlorine: While chlorine is released from bleaching powder, it is the HOCl (formed from chlorine in water) that provides the actual antimicrobial effect, not elemental chlorine itself. D. H? (Hydrogen ion): H? is not directly responsible for antimicrobial activity. Although pH affects the equilibrium between HOCl and OCl?, it is HOCl that has the potent antimicrobial action.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of donovanosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Klebsiella (Calymmatobacterium) granulomatis Explanation: Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a chronic sexually transmitted infection characterized by painless, progressive ulcerative genital lesions. It is caused by: Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis), a Gram-negative intracellular bacillus. It produces Donovan bodies, which are safety-pin-shaped intracellular inclusions seen within macrophages on Giemsa or Wright stain. The infection causes granulomatous inflammation, leading to beefy red ulcers that bleed easily. Incorrect Options: A. Haemophilus ducreyi Causes chancroid, a painful genital ulcer with painful lymphadenopathy (bubo). Unlike donovanosis, chancroid is acute and often associated with suppurative inguinal nodes. C. Leishmania donovani Causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), not genital ulcers. It affects internal organs like the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. D. Treponema pallidum Causes syphilis, which typically presents with a painless genital chancre and generalized rash in secondary stage. Spirochete seen on dark field microscopy.

questions.text: Urethritis in males is not caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Haemophilus ducreyi Explanation: Urethritis in males is inflammation of the urethra that typically presents with dysuria (painful urination), urethral discharge, and sometimes itching. It is commonly caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, particularly those affecting the urogenital tract. The most common causes of urethritis include: Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Gonococcus): A classic cause of purulent urethritis. Chlamydia trachomatis: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). Trichomonas vaginalis: A protozoan parasite that can cause nongonococcal urethritis in males, often asymptomatic but still transmissible. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Haemophilus ducreyi This organism causes chancroid, a painful genital ulcer, not urethritis. It does not invade the urethral epithelium or produce urethral symptoms directly. B. Trichomonas vaginalis Though more common in females, it can cause urethritis in males, sometimes asymptomatic but detectable on urethral swabs or urine microscopy. C. Chlamydia trachomatis One of the leading causes of urethritis, particularly nongonococcal urethritis. Often presents with mild or no symptoms. D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae A classic and common cause of urethritis, especially purulent urethritis with thick yellow discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sporothrix schenckii Explanation (Correct Answer): Sporothrix schenckii is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, often called "rose gardener's disease". It is a dimorphic fungus found in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation. Mode of transmission: Classically acquired by traumatic inoculation, such as: A thorn prick Splinters Animal scratches (especially from cats) Clinical presentation: Begins as a painless papule at the site of inoculation. May spread along lymphatics causing nodular lymphangitis, presenting as a chain of nodules. ? Explanation (Incorrect Options): A. Blastomyces dermatitidis Typically acquired by inhalation of spores, not trauma. It causes pulmonary disease and may disseminate to skin, bones, and GU tract. C. Coccidioides immitis Also acquired through inhalation, especially in arid regions like the southwestern U.S. Causes Valley fever (coccidioidomycosis). No link to traumatic entry. D. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Found in South America, typically acquired through inhalation of conidia. Leads to a chronic granulomatous disease primarily affecting lungs and mucous membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about J.E?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Humans are reservoir Explanation (Correct Answer): Japanese Encephalitis (J.E.) is a zoonotic viral infection transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, primarily Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui. Humans are dead-end hosts, not reservoirs. This is because the level of viremia in humans is too low to infect mosquitoes, hence humans do not contribute to further transmission of the virus. Explanation (Incorrect Options): B. Pigs are amplifier hosts True. Pigs develop high-level viremia and can efficiently amplify the virus, making them important in the transmission cycle. C. Transmitted by Culex vishnui True. The Culex vishnui subgroup, including Culex tritaeniorhynchus, is a major vector of J.E., especially in rural and peri-urban areas. D. Vaccination of pigs controls transmission True. Vaccinating pigs or separating them from human habitats reduces the amplification and thus the spread of the virus to humans.

questions.text: In renal transplant recipients, which is likely organism causing reactivation disease within 1-4 months after surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CMV (Cytomegalovirus) Explanation (Correct Answer): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common cause of reactivation disease in renal transplant recipients during the 1 to 4 months post-transplant period. CMV can reactivate from latency due to immunosuppression. It causes a systemic illness with fever, malaise, leukopenia, and organ involvement (e.g., colitis, pneumonitis, retinitis). CMV also contributes to graft rejection and increased susceptibility to other infections. Preemptive therapy or prophylaxis is often used in high-risk patients (CMV-seropositive donor to seronegative recipient). Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. EBV (Epstein–Barr Virus): While EBV can reactivate, it is more often associated with Post-Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorder (PTLD), which typically occurs later (after 6 months or more). C. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV reactivation usually occurs early (within the first month) post-transplant and is generally localized (e.g., mucocutaneous lesions), not systemic. D. VZV (Varicella-Zoster Virus): VZV reactivation (as shingles) is less common in the early post-transplant period and usually occurs months to years later when cellular immunity wanes further.

questions.text: A child develops septic shock following meningitis. On examination the child has a petechial rash on shown in the figure. Which of the following is a gram negative diplococcus that can be the likely etiology?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neisseria meningitidis Explanation (Correct Answer): Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus and a leading cause of bacterial meningitis, especially in children and young adults. It is also the classic agent responsible for meningococcemia, which presents with: Septic shock Petechial or purpuric rash (due to endotoxin-induced capillary leakage and DIC) Rapid progression to multiorgan failure if untreated The presence of petechial rash in a child with meningitis is highly characteristic of meningococcal sepsis. Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa Though a gram-negative bacillus and a cause of sepsis, especially in immunocompromised individuals or burn patients, it is not a diplococcus and typically does not cause meningitis with a petechial rash. C. Streptococcus pneumoniae A common cause of meningitis but it is a Gram-positive diplococcus, not Gram-negative, and doesn't typically cause a petechial rash. D. E. coli A Gram-negative bacillus, often causing neonatal meningitis and urinary tract infections. It is not a diplococcus and rarely associated with a petechial rash.

questions.text: Nosocomial infection after how many hours of hospitalization?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 48 hrs. Explanation (Correct Answer): A nosocomial infection, also known as a hospital-acquired infection (HAI), is defined as an infection that: Develops 48 hours or more after hospital admission, Was not present or incubating at the time of admission. This 48-hour time frame helps distinguish community-acquired infections from those acquired in the hospital setting due to exposure to hospital flora, invasive procedures, or immunocompromised states. Common examples include: Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) Central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI) Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) Surgical site infections (SSI) Explanation of Incorrect Options: B. 72 hrs While some guidelines may use this time point for specific infections (e.g., ventilator-associated pneumonia), the general definition of nosocomial infection starts at 48 hours. C. 96 hrs This is beyond the standard cutoff; not used in accepted definitions for nosocomial infections. D. 7 days Too late — many infections would be categorized as nosocomial well before this time point.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the intestine are caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Entamoeba histolytica Explanation (Correct Answer): Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebiasis, which commonly presents as amoebic dysentery and amoebic liver abscess. In the large intestine, it invades the colonic mucosa and forms characteristic flask-shaped ulcers. These ulcers have a narrow neck at the mucosal surface and broad base extending into the submucosa. Histologically, you can find trophozoites of E. histolytica with ingested red blood cells (RBCs), which is diagnostic. Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. Giardia lamblia Causes non-invasive infection, mostly limited to the small intestine, leading to malabsorption and steatorrhea, not ulcer formation. C. Helicobacter pylori Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, but not the flask-shaped colonic ulcers. It colonizes the stomach and leads to peptic ulcer disease. D. Enterobius vermicularis Also known as pinworm, it causes perianal itching, not intestinal ulcers. It resides in the colon and rectum but does not invade tissue to cause ulceration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture medium used for Legionella?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) BCYE medium (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract medium) Explanation (Correct Answer): Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease, is a fastidious gram-negative bacillus that requires special growth conditions. The Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar is the specific medium used for its culture. BCYE medium contains: L-cysteine and iron salts, which are essential for Legionella's growth. Charcoal, which neutralizes toxic compounds. Colonies typically appear after 3–5 days of incubation in humidified conditions. This medium is the gold standard for the isolation of Legionella from clinical specimens like sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, or lung biopsy. Explanation of Incorrect Options: B. MacConkey agar Used for gram-negative enteric bacilli like E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, etc. Legionella does not grow on MacConkey. C. Baird Parker agar Selective medium for the isolation of Staphylococcus aureus, not suitable for Legionella. D. Sabouraud dextrose agar Commonly used for fungal cultures, not appropriate for bacterial species like Legionella.

questions.text: Special stain used for Cryptococcus is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucicarmine stain Explanation (Correct Answer): Cryptococcus neoformans is a yeast known for its polysaccharide capsule. The mucicarmine stain is a special stain that specifically highlights the thick capsule of Cryptococcus in a bright red or pink color. This is very useful in tissue biopsy or cytology specimens to distinguish Cryptococcus from other yeasts. The capsule is a key virulence factor and helps in diagnosis. Mucicarmine stain is the best stain for visualizing the capsule of Cryptococcus. Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. ZN stain (Ziehl-Neelsen stain) Used primarily for acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not stain Cryptococcus. B. Gram stain Cryptococcus can be gram-positive, but the capsule is not visualized well by Gram stain. D. Malachite green Used as a spore stain (e.g., for Bacillus species). It does not highlight Cryptococcus capsules.

questions.text: A 36 years old male patient complains of cough, cold, fever. His sputum is rusty and is negative for TB. He has a history of travel to china and had consumed crab. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paragonimus westermani Explanation: Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke causing paragonimiasis, a parasitic infection acquired by eating undercooked or raw freshwater crustaceans, such as crabs or crayfish. It is endemic in parts of East Asia including China. Clinical features: Patients present with cough, rusty sputum (blood-tinged), fever, and chest pain — symptoms mimicking pulmonary tuberculosis. Diagnosis: Sputum may contain characteristic eggs of Paragonimus. Sputum is negative for TB, but clinical features and history of crab consumption support paragonimiasis. Explanation of Other Options (Incorrect): B. Fasciola hepatica Causes fascioliasis, primarily a liver fluke infection affecting the liver and bile ducts, not the lungs. Transmitted by ingestion of watercress, not crab. C. Fasciolopsis buski Large intestinal fluke causing gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and malabsorption, not respiratory symptoms. D. Entamoeba histolytica Causes amoebic dysentery and liver abscess but not respiratory symptoms or rusty sputum.

questions.text: Microbiological test for diagnosing Leptospira infection is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) Explanation: The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the gold standard serological test for diagnosing Leptospira infection (Leptospirosis). How it works: Patient serum is mixed with live cultures of different Leptospira serovars. If antibodies are present, they agglutinate (clump) the bacteria, which can be seen under the microscope. Why it is preferred: It is highly specific and sensitive, allowing identification of the infecting serovar and confirmation of diagnosis. Explanation of Other Options (Incorrect): A. Cold agglutination Used primarily to diagnose Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, not Leptospira. B. Standard agglutination This refers to simpler agglutination tests, but MAT is a specialized microscopic agglutination test with live organisms, which is more specific. D. None of the above Incorrect because MAT is a recognized, standard diagnostic test.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Japanese encephalitis virus. Why Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV)? Appearance: Japanese encephalitis virus is a flavivirus, belonging to the family Flaviviridae. Under electron microscopy, it appears as a small, spherical, enveloped virus with surface projections, characteristic of flaviviruses. Endemic regions: JEV is prevalent in Asia, including India, and is a major cause of viral encephalitis in these regions. Clinical relevance: It causes encephalitis, especially in children and rural populations near rice fields and pig farming areas. Why not the others? A. Yellow fever virus Also a flavivirus, but mainly endemic in Africa and South America, not India. Electron microscopic appearance is similar but less relevant here. B. Dengue virus Another flavivirus with similar morphology but causes a different clinical syndrome (dengue fever, hemorrhagic fever), not primarily encephalitis. D. Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) virus KFD is a tick-borne flavivirus endemic in specific forest areas of India, but morphology and clinical syndrome differ. KFD virus is less commonly visualized and is associated with hemorrhagic symptoms and febrile illness.

questions.text: Disc diffusion method is also known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Kirby Bauer technique. Why Kirby Bauer technique? The disc diffusion method is a standard laboratory technique used to assess the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics. In this method, antibiotic-impregnated paper discs are placed on an agar plate inoculated with the test organism. After incubation, zones of inhibition around the discs indicate sensitivity or resistance. This method was standardized and popularized by Kirby and Bauer in the 1960s, hence the name Kirby-Bauer technique. Why not the others? B. VDRL Stands for Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test, which is a serological test for syphilis, unrelated to antibiotic susceptibility testing. C. Dark field microscopy A microscopic technique used to visualize spirochetes like Treponema pallidum directly; not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing. D. None of the above Incorrect because Kirby Bauer technique is the correct synonym.

questions.text: Rubella virus belongs to which family?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation: Rubella virus is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus. It is the only member of the Rubivirus genus within the Togaviridae family. It causes German measles (rubella), which is usually mild but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if infection occurs during pregnancy. Incorrect options: A. Reoviridae: Includes rotaviruses, double-stranded RNA viruses. C. Picornaviridae: Includes poliovirus, rhinovirus, and enteroviruses. D. Orthomyxoviridae: Includes influenza viruses. Let me know if you want a comparison chart of virus families!

questions.text: A 6 years old boy is having symptoms of fever with chills, cough, rapid breathing and chest pain. Culture from sample shows gram positive cocci. Identify the organism from the image given below-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Streptococcus pneumoniae Explanation: Clinical features: Fever with chills Cough, rapid breathing, chest pain All suggest lobar pneumonia, which is common in children. Lab findings: Gram-positive cocci Typically appear as lancet-shaped diplococci on microscopy. Culture often shows colonies that are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcus aureus: Also gram-positive cocci, but typically appears in grape-like clusters, and causes more abscess-forming or cavitating pneumonias. C. Propionibacterium (Cutibacterium acnes): Gram-positive rod; anaerobic; part of skin flora—not typically a cause of pneumonia. D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Acid-fast bacillus, not gram-positive cocci; causes chronic, not acute, pneumonia-like symptoms.

questions.text: Diagnostic test for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test) Explanation: The VDRL test performed on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the standard diagnostic test for neurosyphilis. It detects non-treponemal antibodies produced in response to T. pallidum infection in the central nervous system. Though less sensitive, it is highly specific when positive in CSF. Why other options are incorrect: B. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin): Also a non-treponemal test, but not validated for CSF testing, so not used for neurosyphilis diagnosis. C. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): Historical, complex, and not commonly used now; not specific for neurosyphilis. D. Weil-Felix test: Used for rickettsial infections, not syphilis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Herpes zoster Explanation: Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), the same virus that causes chickenpox. Characteristic features visible in the image (even though not shown here, based on typical case presentations): Grouped vesicles on an erythematous base Unilateral distribution, typically following a dermatomal pattern Associated with burning pain or tingling before the rash appears Most common in older adults or immunocompromised individuals Why other options are incorrect: B. Smallpox: Lesions are centrifugal (more on face/extremities), all lesions are in the same stage of development. C. Chickenpox (Varicella): Lesions are centripetal (more on trunk), appear in crops with different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, crusts) present simultaneously. D. Atopic dermatitis: Chronic, itchy, non-vesicular rash; typically in flexural areas in children.

questions.text: True about triad of congenital rubella syndrome is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PDA, cataract, deafness Explanation: The classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) includes: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) – a common congenital heart defect. Cataracts – due to virus-induced damage to developing lenses. Sensorineural deafness – the most common and often permanent complication. These are hallmark findings when rubella infection occurs during the first trimester of pregnancy. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, deafness → Hepatosplenomegaly may occur but is not part of the classic triad. C. Chorioretinitis, multiorgan failure, pneumonitis → This is more typical of congenital CMV or toxoplasmosis, not rubella. D. None of the above → Incorrect because Option A correctly lists the triad.

questions.text: A patient is having gastrointestinal symptoms such as pain abdomen and distension, bloody and mucus diarrhoea and tenesmus with rectal prolapse. A stool microscopy reveals the presence of typical barrel shaped eggs. Possible causative agent is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trichuris trichiura Explanation: Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is the causative agent of trichuriasis, a parasitic infection of the large intestine. Key features include: Gastrointestinal symptoms: abdominal pain, bloating, bloody and mucus-containing diarrhea. Tenesmus: frequent urge to defecate with little stool passage. Rectal prolapse: particularly in children with heavy worm burden. Stool microscopy shows typical barrel-shaped (lemon-shaped) eggs with bipolar plugs — pathognomonic for T. trichiura. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Campylobacter: Causes bacterial gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea, but does not produce barrel-shaped eggs in stool. B. Giardia lamblia: Causes non-bloody, foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea; no mucus or blood, and eggs/cysts are oval-shaped, not barrel-shaped. C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Causes perianal itching, not typically bloody diarrhea or rectal prolapse, and eggs are asymmetrical with a flattened side.

questions.text: Coxsackie A16 virus causes which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) Explanation: Coxsackie A16 virus, a member of the Picornaviridae family (genus: Enterovirus), is one of the main causative agents of Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease. Key features of HFMD: Fever, followed by a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and mouth. Common in children <5 years old. Usually mild and self-limiting, but can rarely lead to complications. Note: Enterovirus 71 can also cause HFMD and is more often associated with neurological complications. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Yellow fever: Caused by a Flavivirus, transmitted by mosquitoes. C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, a bacterial infection. D. Myocarditis: More commonly caused by Coxsackie B virus, not A16.

questions.text: Following is the peripheral blood smear of a patient. Which of the following vector is involved in transmission?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anopheles Explanation: The question mentions a peripheral blood smear, and although the image isn't shown here, the correct answer suggests Plasmodium species (the parasite responsible for malaria) is observed. In malaria: The peripheral smear typically shows trophozoites, schizonts, or gametocytes of Plasmodium spp. The disease is transmitted by the female Anopheles mosquito. Why other options are incorrect: B. Ixodid tick: Vector for diseases like Lyme disease and Babesiosis, not malaria. C. Tsetse fly: Transmits Trypanosoma brucei, causing African sleeping sickness. D. Sandfly: Transmits Leishmania, causing leishmaniasis, not malaria.

questions.text: Australia antigen in context of hepatitis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) Explanation: Australia antigen was the original name given to HBsAg when it was first discovered in the serum of an Australian aboriginal person. It is a surface protein of the Hepatitis B virus (HBV). Presence of HBsAg in blood indicates an active HBV infection (either acute or chronic). Why other options are incorrect: B. HBcAg: Core antigen; not detectable in serum, only in infected liver cells. C. HBeAg: Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity, but it's different from the surface antigen. D. Anti-HBeAg: Indicates lower infectivity and some immune response to the virus.

questions.text: Parvo B19 virus has tropism for-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Erythroid progenitor cells Explanation: Parvovirus B19 has a strong tropism (affinity) for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. It infects these cells by binding to the P antigen (globoside) on their surface. Key Clinical Implications: Aplastic crisis in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemia). Fifth disease (erythema infectiosum) in children — presents with "slapped cheek" rash. Hydrops fetalis in infected pregnant women (due to fetal anemia). Why other options are incorrect: B. Macrophages, C. T cells, D. B cells: These are not the primary target cells of Parvovirus B19. Other viruses like EBV (B cells) or HIV (T cells, macrophages) have tropism for these.

questions.text: Shingles is caused due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Varicella zoster virus Explanation: Shingles (Herpes zoster) is caused by the reactivation of the Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV), the same virus responsible for chickenpox.
