After primary infection (chickenpox), the virus remains dormant in dorsal root ganglia and can reactivate later in life, causing the characteristic painful, unilateral vesicular rash along a dermatome. Why other options are incorrect: A. Herpes simplex virus: Causes oral and genital herpes, but not shingles. C. Smallpox virus: Eradicated; causes generalized pustular rash, not shingles. D. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Causes warts, not shingles.

questions.text: Sabin Feldman dye test for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Toxoplasma Explanation: The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test used to detect antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii. It is considered the gold standard test for toxoplasmosis. The test works by mixing live Toxoplasma tachyzoites with patient serum and dye; if antibodies are present, the tachyzoites lose their ability to take up the dye (they remain colorless). Why other options are incorrect: A. Hydatid cyst and D. Echinococcus: Related to echinococcosis, diagnosed by imaging and other serologic tests, not the Sabin-Feldman test. C. Ancylostoma: A hookworm, diagnosed by stool examination, not by dye test.

questions.text: Urea breath test is done for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Helicobacter pylori Explanation: The Urea Breath Test detects the presence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the stomach. H. pylori produces the enzyme urease, which breaks down urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide. In this test, the patient ingests urea labeled with a carbon isotope (^13C or ^14C), and if H. pylori is present, labeled CO? is detected in the breath. Why other options are incorrect: A. Campylobacter: A bacterial cause of gastroenteritis, diagnosed by stool culture, not urea breath test. B. Haemophilus: Causes respiratory infections; no urea breath test. C. Histoplasma: A fungal infection, diagnosed by culture or antigen detection.

questions.text: A person presented with multiple draining sinus having Sulphur granules at mandible. Probable organism is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Actinomyces Explanation: Actinomyces israelii is the classic cause of chronic granulomatous infection characterized by: Multiple draining sinuses especially around the mandible (known as lumpy jaw). Presence of “sulfur granules” in pus or discharge — yellowish granules composed of bacterial colonies. Why other options are incorrect: B. Staphylococcus: Can cause abscesses but not sulfur granules or chronic draining sinuses. C. Streptococcus: Typically causes acute infections without sulfur granules. D. Listeria: Causes systemic infections, especially in neonates and immunocompromised, but not draining sinuses or sulfur granules.

questions.text: Pasteurization of milk is done at-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 63 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes Explanation: This is called Low-Temperature Long-Time (LTLT) pasteurization, where milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes to kill most pathogenic bacteria. There is also a High-Temperature Short-Time (HTST) method: 72°C for 15 seconds (not 20 minutes). Option A (72°C for 20 minutes) is incorrect for pasteurization; it's closer to HTST but with a too-long time. Option C (100°C for 20 minutes) corresponds to boiling or sterilization, not pasteurization. Option D (40°C for 60 minutes) is too low to kill pathogens.

questions.text: A patient from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9g/dl, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dengue Explanation: Fever, arthralgia, and petechial rash are classic features of dengue fever. Thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 20,000/mm³) and prolonged bleeding time with a normal clotting time point to platelet dysfunction and vascular fragility typical of dengue hemorrhagic manifestations. The normal WBC count and anemia (Hb 9 g/dL) also fit the picture. Other infections like malaria or typhoid usually don’t cause such a prominent petechial rash or this pattern of bleeding abnormalities. Scrub typhus may cause rash but typically includes other symptoms and different lab findings.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount Explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan parasite causing trichomoniasis, a common sexually transmitted infection (STI). On a wet saline mount, it shows a characteristic twitching or jerky motility due to its flagella. It can be cultured in special media, so option A is incorrect. It does not form cysts; only the trophozoite form is seen in vaginal secretions, so option C is incorrect. It is definitely an STI, so option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leishmania tropica Explanation: The clinical picture of an ulcer with surrounding erythema on the leg in a patient from West Rajasthan is typical of cutaneous leishmaniasis. Microscopy from the biopsy edge showing organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast is characteristic of Leishmania species. Leishmania tropica is the common species causing cutaneous leishmaniasis in India, including Rajasthan. Why other options are incorrect: B. Babesia: Causes a malaria-like illness; no skin ulcers. C. Trypanosoma: Causes sleeping sickness or Chagas disease; no cutaneous ulcers typical in India. D. Histoplasma: A fungal infection causing pulmonary or disseminated disease; no kinetoplast.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl’s eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Explanation: The "owl’s eye" appearance refers to the characteristic intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in cells infected with Cytomegalovirus. CMV can cause a variety of clinical presentations including fever and rash, especially in immunocompromised individuals or congenital infections. Detection of these inclusions in urine epithelial cells supports the diagnosis of CMV infection. Why other options are incorrect: B. Epstein-Barr virus: Causes infectious mononucleosis; no owl’s eye inclusions. C. Herpes simplex virus: Causes vesicular lesions; different inclusion bodies. D. Toxoplasma gondii: A protozoan, no owl’s eye nuclear inclusions.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cholangiocarcinoma Explanation: Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke that infects the biliary ducts. Chronic infection causes inflammation and epithelial hyperplasia of the bile ducts. This chronic irritation is strongly associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer), especially in endemic areas like East Asia. Why other options are incorrect: A. Cervical cancer: Mainly linked to HPV infection. C. Gastric carcinoma: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. D. Bladder carcinoma: Linked to Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed with HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pneumocystis jirovecii Explanation: The patient is HIV positive with poor adherence to ART, making him immunocompromised and susceptible to opportunistic infections. Persistent cough, weight loss, and a negative fungal culture fit the picture of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). On Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining, Pneumocystis jirovecii appears as darkly stained, crescent or “cup-shaped” cysts. It cannot be cultured by routine fungal culture methods, explaining the negative culture. Why other options are incorrect: A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis: Causes paracoccidioidomycosis, usually in South America. B. Histoplasma capsulatum: Shows small intracellular yeasts, not crescent-shaped cysts. C. Coccidioides immitis: Produces large spherules containing endospores, not crescent-shaped cysts.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antigen detection in the stool sample Explanation: Rotavirus is a common cause of viral diarrhea, especially in children. The most common and reliable diagnostic test is detection of rotavirus antigen in stool samples, usually by ELISA or rapid immunochromatographic tests. Antigen detection in blood or antibody detection in serum is not routinely used for diagnosis. Light microscopy of stool cannot detect the virus because rotavirus particles are too small and require special methods.

questions.text: A boy presented with fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Plasmodium falciparum Explanation: The HRP-2 (Histidine-Rich Protein 2) antigen test is specific for detecting Plasmodium falciparum. This rapid diagnostic test (RDT) is widely used for quick diagnosis of falciparum malaria. Other species like P. vivax, P. malariae, and P. ovale do not produce HRP-2, so they are not detected by this antigen.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staph aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache and rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies Explanation: The clinical picture and CSF findings indicate bacterial meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae (pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli). Haemophilus influenzae requires X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors for growth, which it cannot produce itself. On blood agar, it shows satellitism — it grows around colonies of Staphylococcus aureus, which produce the V factor, helping Haemophilus grow. It produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar is false; Haemophilus does not grow well on MacConkey agar. It is not bacitracin sensitive (this is characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes). It does not exhibit alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CSF PCR for viral DNA Explanation: HSV encephalitis diagnosis is best confirmed by detecting HSV DNA in CSF using PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). This test is highly sensitive and specific and is the gold standard. IgM in CSF is less reliable and not commonly used. Tzanck smear is useful for detecting multinucleated giant cells in skin lesions but not in CSF. CSF culture on chick embryo lines is outdated and not practical for HSV diagnosis.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presented with a fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what is the next appropriate method of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear Explanation: In lymphatic filariasis, once a filarial antigen test is positive, the next step is to confirm the presence of microfilariae in the peripheral blood smear (ideally collected at night due to nocturnal periodicity). This helps in species identification (e.g., Wuchereria bancrofti) and in confirming active infection before starting treatment. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Bone marrow biopsy: Not indicated for filarial infection. B. DEC provocation test: Previously used to elicit microfilariae but largely outdated and unnecessary if antigen is already positive. D. Ultrasound of the scrotum: May show "filarial dance sign" in hydrocele, but it's supportive, not confirmatory.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ceftriaxone Explanation: The clinical presentation of dysuria and urethral discharge after unprotected sex, along with gram stain showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci, is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection (gonorrhea). Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is the treatment of choice for gonorrhea due to rising resistance to penicillin and fluoroquinolones. The CDC currently recommends: Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM in a single dose for uncomplicated gonorrhea. Plus doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 7 days) if chlamydial coinfection hasn’t been ruled out. Why other options are incorrect: A. Erythromycin: Less effective and not recommended. B. Azithromycin: Was used in combination therapy, but resistance is increasing. D. Penicillin G: Resistance has made it ineffective for most N. gonorrhoeae strains.

questions.text: A child presented with perianal itching. Swab specimen Shown in the image. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterobius Explanation: The classic symptom of perianal itching, especially worse at night, is highly suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection. The "scotch tape test" or perianal swab often reveals oval, flattened, asymmetrical eggs — a hallmark of Enterobius. These eggs are not typically found in stool and are best seen in the perianal region early in the morning. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris: Causes intestinal symptoms and respiratory signs (Löffler’s syndrome); eggs are found in stool, not on perianal skin. C. Trichiura (Whipworm): Can cause rectal prolapse and dysentery, but not perianal itching. D. Ancylostoma (Hookworm): Causes anemia, not perianal itching.

questions.text: A frequent traveller came with 4 days of remitting fever with abdominal pain and bradycardia. Best diagnostic test to confirm the pathogen is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Blood culture Explanation: The patient's symptoms — remitting fever, abdominal pain, and bradycardia (often described as relative bradycardia or Faget sign) — are highly suggestive of enteric fever (typhoid fever) caused by Salmonella typhi. Blood culture is the gold standard for diagnosing typhoid fever, especially in the first week of illness. It directly detects the bacteria in the bloodstream, offering both confirmation and antibiotic sensitivity. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Widal test: Serological test with limited sensitivity/specificity; often falsely positive or negative, especially in endemic areas or vaccinated individuals. C. Urine culture: Salmonella may be shed in urine but not reliably and not early. D. Stool culture: Useful later in the illness when the organism is shed in feces but not as sensitive as blood culture in early disease.

questions.text: An adult patient from military background admitted with rash, fever, altered sensorium with deficiency of Membrane attacking complex. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neisseria meningitidis Explanation: The case describes an adult with: Rash, fever, altered sensorium → classical features of meningococcal meningitis or septicemia Military background → crowded settings increase risk of outbreaks Deficiency of Membrane Attack Complex (MAC) → patients with complement C5–C9 deficiency are highly susceptible to Neisseria infections, especially Neisseria meningitidis Why the other options are incorrect: A. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Causes pneumonia, especially in alcoholics/ICU, not associated with MAC deficiency. C. Haemophilus influenzae: Can cause meningitis but less linked to MAC deficiency. D. CMV: A viral infection, not typically presenting with rash and MAC complement association.

questions.text: A patient present with painful vesicles as shown in the image, What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Herpes Explanation: The image (commonly associated with the question) typically shows painful vesicles or ulcers on the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes. Caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) — most commonly HSV-2, though HSV-1 can also cause it. Lesions are: Painful Often multiple grouped vesicles on an erythematous base May ulcerate and crust Why the other options are incorrect: A. Chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi): Painful ulcer, but typically soft, with ragged edges and suppurative lymphadenopathy. B. Syphilis (Treponema pallidum): Painless chancre, clean base, firm edges. D. Candidiasis: Usually causes itching, thick white discharge, and satellite lesions, not vesicular ulcers.

questions.text: Patient admitted with bloody diarrhoea after consumption of oysters. Organism exhibits Kanagawa phenomenon. Choose the correct organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vibrio parahaemolyticus Explanation: Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic gram-negative bacterium commonly associated with the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood, especially oysters. It causes acute gastroenteritis, often with bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and sometimes nausea or vomiting. Kanagawa Phenomenon: This refers to beta-hemolysis on a special medium containing high salt and human red blood cells. It is a virulence marker — Kanagawa-positive strains are more likely to be pathogenic and cause severe diarrhea. Why other options are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus: Causes food poisoning with rapid-onset vomiting; not linked to oysters or bloody diarrhea. C. Campylobacter jejuni: Causes bloody diarrhea but not linked to Kanagawa phenomenon or seafood specifically. D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, not acute gastroenteritis from oysters.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Coccidioides immitis Explanation: Desert rheumatism is a term used to describe the hypersensitivity complex associated with Coccidioidomycosis, caused by Coccidioides immitis (also C. posadasii). It typically occurs in endemic areas like the southwestern United States (e.g., Arizona, California), especially in desert regions. Features of Desert Rheumatism (Coccidioidomycosis): Fever Arthralgia (joint pain) Erythema nodosum (painful red nodules, usually on the shins) Cough or mild respiratory symptoms This syndrome reflects the body’s immune response rather than direct fungal invasion. Why other options are incorrect: A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis: Causes paracoccidioidomycosis, common in South America (not associated with desert climates). B. Candida albicans: Causes mucocutaneous or systemic candidiasis, not desert rheumatism. C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Primarily causes meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, not linked to desert regions.

questions.text: Broad base budding yeasts seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Blastomycosis Explanation: Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, is classically identified by the presence of broad-based budding yeasts in tissue specimens. The organism appears as: Thick-walled yeast Broad-based buds Size: 8–15 µm This morphological feature is diagnostic and helps differentiate it from other fungal infections. Why other options are incorrect: A. Histoplasmosis (Histoplasma capsulatum): Shows intracellular small oval yeasts, often within macrophages. C. Candidiasis (Candida spp.): Shows budding yeasts with pseudohyphae, not broad-based buds. D. Coccidioidomycosis (Coccidioides immitis): Shows spherules with endospores, not budding yeasts.

questions.text: A female patient admitted with UTI Coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant Staphylococcus, >104 grown in culture. It indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) UTI Explanation: The patient has: Urinary tract infection symptoms Significant colony count (>10? CFU/mL) on culture Growth of a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus that is novobiocin resistant These findings point toward Staphylococcus saprophyticus, a common cause of UTI in young sexually active females. Key Features of Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Gram-positive, coagulase-negative Novobiocin resistant (helps distinguish it from Staph epidermidis, which is novobiocin sensitive) Second most common cause of community-acquired UTI after E. coli in young women Why other options are incorrect: B. Commensal: Although coagulase-negative staph can be commensals, S. saprophyticus in significant quantity from a symptomatic patient is pathogenic. C. Contamination: High colony count and clinical symptoms rule this out. D. Collect 3 consecutive samples: This is more relevant for blood cultures in bacteremia workup, not necessary for UTI diagnosis with clear findings.

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer came with Fever, Calf tenderness, Conjunctival suffusion, Retroorbital pain and Hypokalaemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Leptospira Explanation: The clinical features include: Fever Calf tenderness (classic for leptospirosis) Conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva without pus) Retroorbital pain Hypokalemia These are typical signs of Leptospirosis, a zoonotic infection commonly seen in farmers exposed to water contaminated with urine of infected animals. Why other options are incorrect: A. Malaria: Fever and chills common, but calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion are not typical. B. Dengue: Retroorbital pain is common, but calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion are not characteristic; dengue usually causes thrombocytopenia, not hypokalemia. D. Influenza: Presents with fever and body aches but lacks calf tenderness and conjunctival suffusion.

questions.text: A south Asian fruit farmer admitted with fever, breathlessness and encephalitis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) NIPAH Explanation: A South Asian fruit farmer presenting with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis is highly suggestive of Nipah virus infection. Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus transmitted from fruit bats or contaminated fruit. Common in South and Southeast Asia, especially among people exposed to fruit bats or pig farms. Presents with: Acute febrile illness Respiratory symptoms (breathlessness) Encephalitis (altered sensorium, seizures) Why other options are incorrect: A. Ebola: Causes hemorrhagic fever, mostly in Africa. B. Zika: Mostly causes mild illness, rash, conjunctivitis, and birth defects, but not encephalitis or breathlessness typically. C. Malaria: Can cause encephalopathy but breathlessness and association with fruit farming less likely.

questions.text: A child admitted with Chorioretinitis, Hydrocephalus, Intracranial calcifications - what is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Toxoplasmosis Explanation: The classic triad in congenital toxoplasmosis includes: Chorioretinitis (inflammation of the retina and choroid) Hydrocephalus Intracranial calcifications (typically diffuse or scattered) This triad strongly suggests congenital toxoplasmosis, caused by Toxoplasma gondii infection during pregnancy. Why other options are less likely: A. Rubella: Causes cataracts, deafness, and PDA but not typically intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus. B. CMV: Also causes intracranial calcifications but they are typically periventricular; hydrocephalus is less common. D. Zika: Associated with microcephaly and brain calcifications but not the full triad above.

questions.text: A sickle cell patient developed aplastic crisis following a viral infection. Choose the correct agent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Parvovirus B19 Explanation: Parvovirus B19 is the classic cause of aplastic crisis in patients with hemolytic anemias such as sickle cell disease. The virus infects and destroys erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, causing a sudden cessation of red blood cell production. This leads to a rapid drop in hemoglobin and can precipitate an aplastic crisis. Why other options are incorrect: B. EBV: Causes infectious mononucleosis but not aplastic crisis in sickle cell patients. C. HBV: Causes hepatitis; no direct link with aplastic crisis. D. CMV: Can cause marrow suppression but Parvovirus B19 is the classic agent for aplastic crisis in sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed EHEC 0157:H7 infection. Here H indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: PLHIV-foul smelling stool. On microscopy no cyst / ova present. A 200micrometer larva present. What is the pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Strongyloides stercoralis Explanation: In PLHIV (People Living with HIV) with foul-smelling stool and no cysts/ova on microscopy, the presence of a 200 micrometer larva strongly suggests Strongyloides stercoralis infection. Strongyloides is a nematode that releases larvae (not ova) in stool, which is unique among intestinal parasites. It can cause severe disseminated infection in immunocompromised patients (like HIV). Why other options are incorrect: B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Eggs (ova) are usually seen in stool, not larvae. C. Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm): Also ova in stool, not larvae. D. Schistosoma mansoni: Eggs are seen in stool; it’s a blood fluke, not a nematode.

questions.text: 2-year-old child came with watery diarrhoea. EM image shown here. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rota virus Explanation: The 2-year-old child with watery diarrhea and an electron microscopy (EM) image showing a characteristic virus is most consistent with Rotavirus. Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe watery diarrhea in young children worldwide. On EM, it appears as a wheel-shaped virus (hence the name "rota" meaning wheel). Why other options are incorrect: A. Norwalk virus (Norovirus): Causes gastroenteritis but mostly in older children and adults; EM appearance is different. B. Adenovirus: Can cause diarrhea but less commonly in this age group and different morphology. C. ECHO virus: An enterovirus, causes aseptic meningitis and other illnesses, not typically severe watery diarrhea in toddlers.

questions.text: A women came with chronic history of fever, lower limb swelling. Microfilaria image shown here. Choose the correct pathogen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wuchereria bancrofti Explanation: A woman with: Chronic fever Lower limb swelling (likely lymphedema or elephantiasis) Microfilaria seen on microscopy …is classic for lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Key identifying features of W. bancrofti microfilaria: Sheathed microfilaria Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail (important to differentiate from Brugia species) Commonly found in night blood samples Why other options are incorrect: A. Brugia malayi: Also causes lymphatic filariasis, but the terminal nuclei are distinctively separated. B. Mansonella spp.: Causes skin and subcutaneous infections, not typically associated with lower limb swelling. D. Loa loa: Causes Calabar swellings and is found in subcutaneous tissues, not lymphatics.

questions.text: An adult man came with dysuria, discharge from urethra with h/o unprotected sex. Gram stain image shown here, Best medium for this organism is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thayer Martin agar Explanation: A man presents with: Dysuria Urethral discharge History of unprotected sexual intercourse Gram stain likely shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci → classic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae Best medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Thayer Martin agar: A selective medium that contains antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to suppress the growth of contaminants and support only Neisseria species. Why other options are incorrect: B. MacConkey agar: For gram-negative enteric bacilli; Neisseria doesn’t grow well on it. C. Chocolate agar: Supports Neisseria but not selective – overgrowth by other flora possible. D. TCBS agar: Used for Vibrio species.

questions.text: Young boy used wash his contact lenses in tap water / Unhygienic lens fluid. Developed keratitis. Microscopy revealed organism with spikes. Choose the correct one
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acanthamoeba Explanation: A young boy with contact lens use and poor hygiene, followed by keratitis, and microscopy showing organism with spikes, strongly points to Acanthamoeba keratitis. Key Features of Acanthamoeba: Free-living amoeba found in tap water, soil, and lens solution. Causes severe keratitis in contact lens users. Microscopy may show double-walled cysts with spiny projections ("thorn-like" spikes). Why the other options are incorrect: A. Balantidium: Causes colitis, not keratitis. B. Pseudomonas: Can cause keratitis, especially in contact lens users, but does not appear spiked under microscopy. D. Staph aureus: Can cause eye infections but is gram-positive cocci, not spiked organisms on microscopy.

questions.text: An adult man came with a clinical condition shown in the image. Gram negative diplococci found in Gram stain. What is the treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cefixime Explanation: An adult man presents with: Urethral discharge Gram stain showing gram-negative diplococci This is classic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Treatment of choice: Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against N. gonorrhoeae. Alternatively, Ceftriaxone (IM) is the most widely recommended treatment in guidelines, but Cefixime (oral) is used when injection is not feasible. Why others are incorrect: A. Azithromycin: Previously used in combination for gonorrhea + chlamydia, but increasing resistance has limited its use. B. Penicillin: Not preferred due to widespread resistance in N. gonorrhoeae. D. Doxycycline: Used to treat chlamydia, not effective for gonorrhea alone. Current CDC recommendation (2024): Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose is preferred. Doxycycline may be added if chlamydial co-infection is not ruled out.

questions.text: Infection in CVC found in a patient in ICU. Gram positive ovoid budding organism seen in microscopy. What is the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Candida Explanation: A patient in the ICU with a central venous catheter (CVC) who develops infection, and microscopy shows gram-positive ovoid budding organisms, is most likely infected with Candida. Key Points: Candida is a yeast (fungus), appearing as gram-positive, ovoid, budding cells under the microscope. CVCs are a major risk factor for catheter-associated candidemia, especially in ICU settings with broad-spectrum antibiotic use or immunosuppression. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Staph epidermidis: Gram-positive cocci; common in catheter infections but appears in clusters (not budding yeast). C. E. coli: Gram-negative bacilli; not ovoid or budding. D. Staph aureus: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, not budding organisms. Summary: Budding yeast cells → Candida Common in ICU/CVC patients Confirmed by culture and may require antifungal therapy (e.g., echinocandins or fluconazole, depending on susceptibility).

questions.text: A farmer admitted with subcutaneous wound with discharge on his foot. Microscopy of white granule shows gram positive filamentous rods. What is the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nocardia Explanation: A farmer with a subcutaneous wound and discharge containing white granules, showing gram-positive filamentous rods on microscopy, is classic for Nocardia infection. Key Identifiers: Nocardia: Gram-positive, filamentous, partially acid-fast. Found in soil – hence higher risk in farmers and gardeners. Causes cutaneous nocardiosis or mycetoma (when presenting with draining sinuses and granules). White granules in discharge = suggestive of mycetoma. Why the others are incorrect: A. Staphylococcus aureus: Gram-positive cocci, not filamentous. Can cause soft tissue infections, but no granules. B. Histoplasma: A fungus, usually causes pulmonary or systemic infections, not draining subcutaneous lesions with granules. D. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, often from rose thorns. Appears as cigar-shaped yeast in tissue, not filamentous gram-positive rods.

questions.text: Function of IL8
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chemotaxis Explanation: IL-8 (Interleukin-8) is a chemokine primarily involved in the chemotaxis of neutrophils. It is secreted by macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cells in response to pro-inflammatory stimuli such as IL-1 and TNF-α. IL-8 acts by binding to CXCR1 and CXCR2 receptors on neutrophils, guiding them toward sites of infection or tissue injury. This recruitment of neutrophils is crucial for initiating the innate immune response, allowing for phagocytosis of pathogens and subsequent inflammation. IL-8 does not affect lymphocytes or fever mechanisms directly but plays a central role in early immune defense through neutrophil activation and migration. Option B: Lymphocyte proliferation – Incorrect. This is primarily the function of IL-2, which is produced by activated T cells. IL-2 promotes the growth, proliferation, and differentiation of T cells, B cells, NK cells, and monocytes. Option C: TH1 activation – Incorrect. IL-12 is the major cytokine involved in the differentiation of naïve T cells into TH1 cells. IL-8 has no direct role in T helper cell subset differentiation. Option D: Fever – Incorrect. Fever is mainly induced by IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, which act on the hypothalamus to raise the body temperature. IL-8 is not pyrogenic and does not contribute to the febrile response.

questions.text: Patient from Bihar admitted with splenomegaly and features of leishmaniasis. What is the vector?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phlebotomus Explanation: The vector for leishmaniasis in India, including endemic areas like Bihar, is the Phlebotomus sandfly, specifically Phlebotomus argentipes. These sandflies transmit Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), when they bite humans and introduce the promastigote form of the parasite into the bloodstream. The disease is characterized by prolonged fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly (especially splenomegaly), and pancytopenia. Phlebotomus sandflies breed in moist soil and are active in dusk and dawn, making vector control an important aspect of disease prevention. Option B: Rat flea – Incorrect. Rat fleas, particularly Xenopsylla cheopis, are vectors of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, not leishmaniasis. Option C: Black fly – Incorrect. Black flies (Simulium species) transmit Onchocerca volvulus, the causative agent of onchocerciasis (river blindness), not leishmaniasis. Option D: Chrysops fly – Incorrect. The Chrysops fly, or deer fly, is the vector for Loa loa, the filarial worm responsible for loiasis, not leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Best PCR for identifying a syndrome/ Multiple causative agents is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiplex PCR Explanation: Multiplex PCR is the best type of PCR for identifying a syndrome with multiple causative agents. This method allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple targets in a single PCR reaction by using more than one pair of primers. It is particularly useful in syndromic diagnosis (e.g., respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, meningitis) where a range of pathogens—viruses, bacteria, or parasites—can cause similar symptoms. By detecting several pathogens at once, it reduces time, cost, and sample requirement, making it a preferred tool in clinical diagnostics for syndromic panels. Option A: RT PCR – Incorrect. Reverse transcription PCR is used when the target is RNA, such as in RNA viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Influenza). While sensitive and quantitative, it's not designed specifically to detect multiple pathogens at once unless multiplexed, which would still fall under multiplex RT-PCR. Option C: Nested PCR – Incorrect. Nested PCR is a highly sensitive technique used to reduce non-specific binding in products from conventional PCR. It involves two sets of primers and two successive PCR reactions. It is excellent for detecting low levels of DNA, but not ideal for detecting multiple agents simultaneously. Option D: Conventional PCR – Incorrect. This is the standard form of PCR targeting one gene or organism at a time. While useful, it is not efficient for detecting multiple pathogens and lacks the high-throughput nature required for syndromic diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl child came with her mother with the complaints of perianal itching and h/o worm around anus. Microscopy shown in the image. Choose the correct organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Enterobius vermicularis The classical symptom of perianal itching, especially at night, in a child is pathognomonic for Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm). The eggs are flattened on one side and are seen in the perianal region using the Scotch tape test. Transmission occurs via fecal-oral route, especially in crowded environments like schools.

questions.text: A patient admitted with h/o cough and sputum. Cavitation in lung is present. Budding yeast cells in macrophage. SDA agar microscopy shown in the image. Identify this
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Histoplasma capsulatum Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to certain regions. It causes cavitary lung lesions and is intracellular—often seen within macrophages. On SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar), mold form shows tuberculate macroconidia. It mimics TB and is common in bird droppings and bat-inhabited caves.

questions.text: A patient came with the h/o swelling of foot, multiple sinuses and discharging black granules as shown in the image. What will be seen on microscopy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Septate hyphae This is eumycetoma, characterized by painless swelling, discharging sinuses, and black granules. Common agent is Madurella. Microscopy shows septate hyphae..

questions.text: A 25-year-old sewage worker came with fever, weakness and conjunctival suffusion for one week duration. Lab diagnosis reveals increased ALT, Bilirubin and decreased urine output. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Weil’s Disease Weil’s disease is a severe form of leptospirosis (caused by Leptospira interrogans). Common in sewage workers. Features include fever, jaundice, renal failure, and conjunctival suffusion. Diagnosis: serology (MAT) and dark field microscopy from blood/urine.

questions.text: A child presents with sore throat. Pathogen diagnosed as Streptococcus pyogenes. Which structure facilitates adhesion of this pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lipoteichoic acid Adherence of Streptococcus pyogenes to epithelial cells is facilitated by lipoteichoic acid, which anchors to host fibronectin. M protein prevents phagocytosis. Capsule is made of hyaluronic acid but non-immunogenic.

questions.text: A child came with bloody diarrhoea after consumption milk. Gram negative rods present. Choose the appropriate causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Campylobacter jejuni C. jejuni causes bloody diarrhea, often following undercooked poultry or contaminated milk. It's a curved Gram-negative rod, grows at 42°C, and is oxidase positive. Other choices are less likely: C. perfringens causes toxin-mediated diarrhea, Vibrio is usually associated with seafood.

questions.text: College student with severe sore throat, fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Likely agent is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) EBV This is infectious mononucleosis. EBV infects B cells via CD21. Classic features: posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, atypical lymphocytes on smear. EBV is detected by heterophile antibody (Monospot test).

questions.text: Young girl presented with vesicles around mouth and trigeminal neuralgia. Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells and intranuclear inclusions.What is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HSV HSV-1 typically causes cold sores around the mouth and can reactivate in trigeminal ganglion. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells and Cowdry A inclusions. CMV shows owl's eye inclusions; EBV does not cause vesicles.

questions.text: Patient with leg swelling since 1 year. Biopsy shown in the image. What is the mechanism for his swelling?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lymphatic Obstruction Chronic leg swelling with lymphatic pathology (e.g., filariasis, tumor obstruction) leads to lymphedema. This reduces lymphatic drainage, leading to protein-rich interstitial fluid accumulation. Other causes like hypoalbuminemia cause pitting edema due to oncotic pressure.

questions.text: Abattoir presents with Malignant pustule. Mc Faydean reaction with polychrome methylene blue is positive. Choose the correct causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B.anthracis Anthrax causes malignant pustule (painless black eschar). Diagnosis by McFadyean reaction (purple capsule with polychrome methylene blue). B. anthracis is a Gram-positive rod with capsule made of poly-D-glutamic acid.

questions.text: A patient presents with an abscess. Microscopy of the aspirate shows Gram Positive filamentous bacteria and positive for Modified Acid-fast stain. Paraffin bait technique for isolation. What is the agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nocardia Nocardia is a Gram-positive filamentous bacterium, partially acid-fast, aerobic, and urease positive. Distinguished from Actinomyces (anaerobic, not acid-fast). Isolated via paraffin bait technique, it causes brain abscesses, lung infections, and cutaneous lesions.

questions.text: A college student found have meningitis. Prophylaxis to household contacts is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rifampicin Close contacts of a meningococcal meningitis case need chemoprophylaxis. Rifampicin is the drug of choice (600 mg BID for 2 days). Alternatives: Ciprofloxacin or Ceftriaxone in pregnancy. Penicillin treats the infection, not for prophylaxis.

questions.text: A patient admitted with meningitis. Choose the test to identify organisms on syndromic basis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiplex PCR Multiplex PCR can detect multiple pathogens from one sample in a syndromic approach. Rapid, sensitive, and detects bacteria, viruses, fungi from CSF in suspected meningitis. Conventional PCR targets single pathogen, nested PCR increases sensitivity, RFLP is for typing.

questions.text: 20 y/o patient developed fever and neck rigidity with hypotension. H/o skin rash present. Succumbed to death in the hospital. Gross image of brain given after autopsy. Choose the Causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neisseria meningitidis Rapid-onset meningitis with petechial/purpuric rash, hypotension, and death is classic for meningococcemia. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome). N. meningitidis is Gram-negative diplococcus, oxidase positive, and ferments glucose and maltose. Autopsy macroscopically - - The leptomeninges (pia mater and arachnoid) covering the brain appear cloudy or opaque due to the presence of pus and inflammatory exudate.

questions.text: A patient admitted with cough & Sputum. BAL microscopy reveals a fungi showing septate hyphae with dichotomous branching. Choose the appropriate agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Aspergillus Aspergillus spp. show acute-angle (45°), septate, dichotomously branching hyphae in tissue (especially in BAL or biopsy). It causes invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised, or aspergilloma in pre-existing cavities. Mucor has broad, ribbon-like non-septate hyphae.

questions.text: A female patient presents with urethritis and arthritis. Gonococcal infection is suspected. Due to deficiency in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) C5–C9 deficiency Deficiency of terminal complement components (MAC complex) increases susceptibility to Neisseria infections—especially N. gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis. C5-C9 form membrane attack complex responsible for killing Gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A female came with the Toxoplasma infection positive 4 years ago. what will you do now
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Continue pregnancy If Toxoplasma IgG positive and IgM negative, and infection occurred years ago, there is no risk to fetus. No need to terminate or perform amniocentesis. Prophylaxis not needed unless immunocompromised. Only recent/acute infection in pregnancy poses risk.
